title: Processes - Average Value of a Function

content.question: Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be a continuous function defined on the closed interval <math alttext="2 is less than or equal to x, which is less than or equal to k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>≤</mo><mi>k</mi></mrow></math>, where <math alttext="k greater than 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>></mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></math>. If the average value of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> on this interval is <math alttext="6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="the integral from 2 to k, of, f of x, d x, equals 42" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mo>∫</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msubsup><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle><mo>=</mo><mn>42</mn></mrow></math>, then <math alttext="k equals" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo></mrow></math>

topic.text: 8.1: Finding the Average Value of a Function on an Interval

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
